posts.name:
Sandeep Pal
Sandeep Pal
posts.content:
For the first time in 40 years, Maruti Suzuki‚Äôs reign as the leader in India‚Äôs car market has been overtaken. In 2024, Tata Motors claimed the top spot with the Tata Punch, selling over 2.02 lakh units, surpassing the Maruti Suzuki Wagon R‚Äôs 1.91 lakh units.

This marks a pivotal moment in the Indian automobile industry. The growing preference for compact SUVs and premium vehicles is reshaping the market, breaking the decades-long dominance of affordable hatchbacks‚Äîa segment synonymous with Maruti Suzuki‚Äôs success.

For Maruti Suzuki, this shift represents a new challenge, as the market evolves toward more feature-rich and versatile vehicles. Meanwhile, Tata Motors‚Äô rise underscores its ability to cater to these changing consumer preferences.

The Indian car market is entering a new era, one driven by innovation and an increasing demand for premium and SUV models.

||

posts.name:
Krishna Kiran
Krishna Kiran
posts.content:
1 story of a brutal meeting with the boss. 3 career lessons. 

One day, Elon asked a brutal question to Lucas Hughes a financial analyst who oversees the costs of the Raptor engine. The same engine that will make humans multi-planetary.

[Elon] "What are the best parts in Raptor as judged by the idiot index?"

[Lucas responded] "I'm not sure."

Elon chewed him out: "You better be sure in the future you know these things off the top of your head. If you ever come into a meeting and do not know what the idiot parts are, your resignation will be accepted immediately."
"How can you not know what the best and worst parts are?"

[Lucas] "I know the cost chart down to the smallest part. I just don't know the cost of the raw materials of those parts."

[Elon] "What are the worst five parts?"

When Lucas looked at his computer to see if he could calculate an answer...

[Elon said]: "NO! Don't look at your screen. Just name one. You should know the problematic parts."

[Lucas] "There's the half nozzle jacket. I think it costs $13,000."

[Elon] "It's made of a single piece of steel. How much does that material cost?"

[Lucas] "I think a few thousand dollars?"

[Elon] "No. It's just steel. It's about 200 bucks. You have very badly failed. If you don't improve, your resignation will be accepted. This meeting is over. Done."

The following day, Lucas was back, and this time he was prepared.
He presented the 20 worst "idiot index" parts for Elon.
And noticed there was a theme: the worst parts were those that required a lot of
high-precision machining, like pumps and fairings.

[Lucas] "We need to cut out as much of the machining as possible,"

Elon smiled. He was impressed.

The meeting ended with an ambitious plan to get the cost of the Raptor engine from $2 million down to $200,000 in one year.

When Isaacson later asked Elon if he felt he had been too harsh on Lucas,

Elon said: "I try to criticize the action, not the person. We all make mistakes. What matters is whether a person has a good feedback loop, can seek criticism from others, and can improve. Physics does not care about hurt feelings. It cares about whether you got the rocket right."

Lessons:
1) Be in the details. Know your numbers. Can you use the Idiot index to innovate on your team?
2) Lesson - Don‚Äôt try to fix your leader. You can‚Äôt. Either adapt or move. Many CEOs are direct because they don‚Äôt have the time/energy/skills to teach their team. Jeff Bezos and Steve Jobs were the same. Elon thought he criticized the action, not the person. But the person felt otherwise.
Could Elon have been more polished?
Definitely, but he chose what works best for him and was able to bring the best out of his team.
Lucas adapted and then moved on.
3) Have short feedback loops.

Story Credits: Walter Isaacson. Lessons distilled by Krishna.

The quality of your thinking = the quality of the ideas you consume.
I keep sharing no-fluff career and startup growth ideas everyday. Follow along.

comments.commentText: thank you for sharing

posts.content:
ùêÇùê®ùê´ùê©ùê®ùê´ùêöùê≠ùêû ùêèùê®ùê•ùê¢ùê≠ùê¢ùêúùê¨ ùêáùêÄùêìùêÑùêí ùêåùêû ùêüùê®ùê´ ùê§ùêßùê®ùê∞ùê¢ùêßùê† ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùê¨!

I‚Äôve made some big career switches,
Not just between companies but across domains‚Äîfrom taxation to investment banking, and then to working with startups.

Along the way, I learned that career success doesn‚Äôt require playing office politics. It‚Äôs all about working smart and staying visible.

Here are 7 little-known career hacks that actually work:

Make Your Work Visible
After completing a key project, share the success.
"Just wrapped up [Project Name], and I‚Äôm thrilled with the results. A proud moment for the team!"

This positions you as someone who delivers and values teamwork.

Master Follow-Ups
Summarize meeting action points and cc decision-makers.

Pro tip: This makes you look proactive and dependable.

Own the Spotlight
Volunteer for 5 minutes in team meetings.
Even small updates build confidence and improve how you're perceived.

Small Wins, Big Picture
Each week, link one small achievement to a larger goal.
Example: "Streamlined [X task], saving 3 hours. Aligns with our efficiency targets."

Be the Connector
Introduce two people in your network to each other.
People remember connectors, and it positions you as invaluable.

Learn to Say "No" Smartly
Don‚Äôt overcommit. Say:
"This sounds important‚Äîcan I prioritize it after [current task]?"
Respect for your boundaries grows your credibility.

Document Your Wins
Keep a folder of achievements, feedback, and metrics.
When appraisal season comes, you‚Äôll have the evidence ready.

You don‚Äôt need tricks to win at work‚Äîjust strategy. Which hack are you trying first?

comments.commentText:
Huste in public
WIN in public
And when you get the spotlight you've been working for, do not shy away :)

Riya Upreti that‚Äôs the best advice! 
step up and own the momentÔ∏è

Riya Upreti I totally agree! Success isn't just about hard work; it's about boldly seizing opportunities and confidently stepping into the spotlight to truly embrace the moment and claim the glory we've earned

posts.name:
Bill Fanter
Bill Fanter
posts.content:
Two people make $200,000 a year.

Which would you rather be?

Person A:

‚Ä¢ Lives in San Francisco
‚Ä¢ Pays $4,000/month rent
‚Ä¢ $7 coffees

Person B:

‚Ä¢ Lives in Mexico
‚Ä¢ Pays $800/month rent
‚Ä¢ $1 coffees

Remote work isn't just changing how we work.

It's changing how wealth is built.

The new wealthy class will be:

‚Ä¢ Location independent
‚Ä¢ Timezone flexible
‚Ä¢ Globally mobile

The office isn't just holding back your freedom.

It's holding back your wealth.

Your zip code shouldn't determine your net worth.

comments.commentText: Person B's got it made.
Nat Berman Agree 100%, my friend!
Nat Berman indeed!

Unfortunately, office buildings are an important source of tax revenue in many cities - NYC, SF, CHI - etc. The real estate taxes are based on the value of the bldgs. Remote work decreases the value of those building and places cities in a catastrophic financial position. Office workers generate revenue for surrounding businesses which in turn also generate tax revenue. It is a domino effect.

The back-to-office mandate is more political than any CEO will admit. Therefore, no matter how wonderful and humanly correct remote work is, the financial connection between offices and economic survival of cities will be prioritized. For better or worse.
Ted Schachter it‚Äôs crazy how society has literally boxed itself into office space being more valuable than just about anything

posts.name:
Matthias Orgler, MSc
Matthias Orgler, MSc
posts.content:
Stop arguing over frameworks and methodologies!

These are NOT what makes you agile.

 The grass is always greener on the other side. Debating whether scrum or kanban or something else is better will not get you anywhere. Sure, some are a better fit for certain circumstances; but if you arent‚Äòt agile, neither choice will make you agile.

 I‚Äòve seen teams across the globe; some were doing scrum, some kanban, many were NOT agile at all with any of these!

To be agile takes a different culture, different values and fundamentally a different view of the human being 

If you cannot adopt this view of the human being, no framework or methodology in the world will ever make you agile.

comments.commentText: Nobody reads The Agile Manifesto anymore. Maybe nobody ever did. Whichever process and methods you use they should support the core values. But people insist on having it the other way around. https://agilemanifesto.org/
Kim Pedersen oh yes. Most read ‚Äúthe other‚Äú manifesto: https://matthiasorgler.com/2024/03/07/the-manifesto-most-organizations-live-by/

Matthias Orgler, MSc Having 30 years of experience with these things in software development projects I have come to think that maybe software development thrives much better when driven by open source projects and that businesses should just adapt and integrate these for their own purposes, using a minimum of software development.

"To be agile takes a different culture, different values and fundamentally a different view of the human being "

Why?

Bryan Finster good question. Thanks! 

Many agile methods build on autonomy, trust, courage, open communication and so on. Fundamentally agility comes from trusting the experts do make decisions. That is tough in many organizations, because they fear to lose alignment and control.They also fear that employees managing themselves would not perform highly enough.

But using frameworks or changing org charts has little effect on that fear of individuals. I often encounter an almost Tayloristic view justifying people management jobs. But if we can‚Äôt trust people and assume positive intent, even if they make mistakes, we cannnot entrust them with decisions (like how or when they work). And with that many agile methods become hollow shells without effect.

I agree that changing a culture is very hard. In my experience, we have to work 1:1 with key leadership positions to help them nudge themselves in a different direction. Help them reflect on the effectiveness of current behavior, past habits and believes, and offer them alternative ways of looking at other people that enable agility. It‚Äôs more psychological work than process work - although as a techy It took me a long time to accept that.

posts.content:
One of the harsh truths of life:

Everyone is jealous of your success.

Nobody is jealous of your journey.

comments.commentText: My book on careers is out now - with 15 career tools, top career mistakes to avoid, how to build the right career mindset and more. Buy it here: www.buildepiccareer.com

Love this post, Warikoo! I guess that means I can brag about my success all I want, but nobody wants to hear about the time I got lost on my way to a meeting and ended up in a cornfield.  Thanks for the reminder to enjoy the journey, not just the destination!

posts.name:
Jorge Franchi, Ph.D.
Jorge Franchi, Ph.D.
posts.content:
Crossing the Gaps: A Leadership Perspective

Watching this snail carefully navigate a gap between two surfaces reminds me of the journey many organizations and individuals face daily. Whether in leadership, HR, or management consulting, we often encounter challenges that feel insurmountable‚Äîuncertain transitions, structural changes, or personal growth hurdles.

This small yet profound act of crossing a gap symbolizes what we strive to do in our work:

‚Ä¢ In Organizational Development: Build strong connections between strategy and execution, bridging silos to foster collaboration.

‚Ä¢ In HR: Design clear paths for employee growth, helping them navigate career transitions with confidence.

‚Ä¢ In Leadership: Provide vision and support, ensuring our teams feel safe to take risks and innovate.

‚Ä¢ In Personal Development: Recognize that progress, even when slow, leads to growth and transformation.

Just like the snail, success isn‚Äôt about speed‚Äîit‚Äôs about intentionality, persistence, and trust in the process. Let‚Äôs keep building environments where individuals and organizations can confidently navigate their own gaps and emerge stronger on the other side.

What strategies do you use to help your teams or clients bridge the gaps they face?

comments.commentText:
What an inspiring analogy! It is a powerful reminder that success is more about persistence, intentionality, and trusting the process than rushing to the finish line.

Thank you for sharing this perspective, it‚Äôs a great call to action to keep building environments where collaboration, growth, and innovation thrive!

Josh SES Packaging Systems Inc.

Thank you, Josh! I truly appreciate your thoughtful reflection. It‚Äôs so true‚Äîtrusting the process and fostering persistence can lead to powerful outcomes. Collaboration and growth indeed pave the way for innovation!
How can we be sure that this snail was careful as opposed to brazen?

Michael G.

Great question, Michael! It‚Äôs interesting to reflect on how subtle the line can be between careful and brazen, depending on perspective. Sometimes what seems cautious can also be seen as bold perseverance.
